content.description:
This was a really cool problem that climbs a face right next to a sharp, crumbly crack starting with a double undercling in a alcove before tackling the face. It is quite rough on the hands though.

Start down in the alcove with a double undercling, a good pocket for the left, a blunt edge for the right, and feet on the kickboard. Decide how you'll take on the face with extremely limited foot options. Make it to the nice sharp jug, and then pull on top.

The sketchy downclimb is to the left of the problem, but it may be easier to jump onto your crashpad.

If you know the history, feel free to chime in and I can update.
content.protection: A crashpad. It has a great, flat landing.
content.location:
The route as well as others are located southeast of the main red rock fins. If coming from the Settlers Park TH, walk up the normal path towards the main outcropping where there is a bench that overlooks Boulder. About 100 yards before the bench, there is a small drainage trail on your right (southeast) that heads to a short visible wall.

This problem is about halfway down the wall.

content.description: This is simple arete climbing with perfect-sized, albeit sandy, cracks.  The landing is terrible and gear placement is highly suspect....
content.location: Between the two collections of fins, this is the NE-most route of the SW fin.

content.description: Start up the pretty cream and grey colored ramp, the crack helps a bit too. At the top of the ramp, get the jug to the right, step up into a stem, and traverse right and up to finish on more decent jugs. Be careful with the suspect rock.
content.protection: A few pads if think you might fall, or TR it.
content.location:
It ascends the obvious, pretty ramp near the far right end of the wall to the right of "

Getcher' Feet Up

".

content.description: Just to the right of the tree, climb a few good slots into nice pockets and an obvious, dark brown, hole-in-the-wall jug about 10 feet up. Trend right slightly for the upper section, which seems more friable, be careful. You can also start about 7 feet to the right on the V3, and traverse into this problem.
content.protection: If you think you might fall, use a lot of pads or a TR.
content.location:
In between "

Black Line Highball

" and "

Getcher' Feet Up

" (just to the right of the tree) is a nice line of slots and pockets. The climbing is a bit trickier for the second half. Beware birds and wasps in the holes.

content.description: The crux would be the SDS if you were to choose to do so.  Ascend the ~80 degree angle on solid pebbles and sandy, deteriorating cracks. Perhaps a safer yet harder problem could be found using only the pebbles....
content.location: This is the northern-most route at the Red Rocks; either begin at Settler's Park and follow the trail all the way around, or start at the Mt. Sanitas side and head West on the wraparound trail.

content.description: This route utilizes a few key pebbles and pockets to ascend the vertical, sandstone fin. The pebbles seem secure; the pockets are not. Climb at your own risk: everything in this area will disintegrate with usage and time.
content.protection: Graceful falling onto a sketchy landing. A pad might help
content.location: Climb the West face of the second fin on the NE formation. From the North side, walk up an easy gully towards a big rock with a little tunnel underneath it; the wall is on your left.  From the south, walk up a third class gully, pull a couple easy 5th moves to gain the ridge of fin #2 (on the left), and either downclimb the route or find an easier method down.

content.description:
If you're dying for a gnarly squeeze on some rough sandstone, this is your crack! One etched tally on the first chockstone is all the evidence of an ascent from who knows how long ago.

P1 (not that it requires a rope): this starts relatively tame (16") with surprisingly solid holds, but then as the first chockstone is neared, it shrinks down to 8".  If it weren't for the chossy sandstone as it widens near the top chockstones, this route would receive another star, but as such, the jamming felt a little insecure up there.

P2: this is mostly 3rd class scrambling with one easy 5th move up another small crack that takes you to the top.
content.protection: A thick T-shirt and some tough pants. One could perhaps sling those chockstones, but why bother?
content.location: On the South side of SW Fin #2 lies a recessed, subtly flaring squeeze chimney with three visible chockstones about 30 feet up.  On its East face lies a vertical, green stripe of lichen with yellow stripes on each side of it. The route I took (with a 29" waist) was on the inner side of the first chockstone, but for you wider folk, an exposed variation nearer the outside looks doable.

content.description:
This problem ascends the right (south) side of first honey colored boulder along this wall.

Start low and right, then grab the huge hueco. Follow up the brim, stay on the face, and finish on top.

Downclimb on the northside.

If you know the history, feel free to chime in and I can update.
content.protection: Crashpad. The landing is not ideal, but it is good enough.
content.location:
The route as well as others are located southeast of the main red rock fins. If coming from the Settlers Park TH, walk up the normal path towards the main outcropping where there is a bench that overlooks Boulder. About 100 yards before the bench, there is a small drainage trail on your right (southeast) that heads to a short visible wall.

This problem is on the first boulder along this wall.

content.description:
This is the straight-in hand crack to chimney on the West Face of the Second Fin of Red Rocks Park.  It is not visible from the loop trial of Red Rocks, a nice feature of the route.

While it has undoubtedly been climbed before, there is no documented ascent, no fixed gear, and no evidence of prior ascents.

JAKS gets excellent winter sun angle in the afternoon and has the feel of a desert spire with Boulder as its backdrop.
content.protection: Standard rack to 4". The rock on JAKS is surprisingly good for Red Rocks and accepts good pro throughout.
content.location: There are four prominent North-South fins on the main formation of Red Rocks.  The route is on the west face of the second fin from East to West.  Approach from either of the third class gullies north or south of the base.  The approach from the north is faster.

content.description:
This problem ascends the left (north) side of first honey colored boulder along this wall.

Start near a tooth looking hold, and follow the crack that's above it. Gain the large heco, and stay on the face. Get another good hold, and you're at the top.

Downclimb on the northside.

If you know the history, feel free to chime in and I can update.
content.protection: Crashpad. The landing is okay, it starts to fall away from the wall.
content.location:
The route as well as others are located southeast of the main red rock fins. If coming from the Settlers Park TH, walk up the normal path towards the main outcropping where there is a bench that overlooks Boulder. About 100 yards before the bench, there is a small drainage trail on your right (southeast) that heads to a short visible wall.

This problem is on the first boulder along this wall.

climbs.name: Getcher' Feet Up Direct
climbs.fa: me and the buds, TR. FA: Seth Boulder

content.description:
Start scrunched on right-facing sidepulls with pretty insecure foot holds, and reach left to a big bulge. Getting on and up the bulge is the crux. Then, climb straight up using the crimpy "

Getcher' Feet Up

" finish.
content.location: Find flared cracks 10 feet to the right of the tree.

content.description: Start on some right-facing sidepulls just to the right of the tree at head height. Get to the big diagonal rail on the right, either cut your feet or heel hook the rail, and traverse it. Above the right side of the rail, use some hidden crimps or the big, vertical rail to stand up better. 2 small crimps and a layback move can get you up. Then look around for some jugs that top you out.
content.protection: Lots of crashpads or a rope.
content.location:
Start to the right of "

Black Line Highball

."

content.description: Start high on two crimps and make big moves to sharp pockets and a jug. Veer right and then left to the top out. Just follow the black streak, and don't fall!
content.protection: 2 or more crashpads and a spotter would be best.
content.location:
This climb is like 20 feet to the right of "

Underthang

" and just left of an obvious tree.
